children.subject: Putting this in the followups because I haven't been in your position exactly, but as a current 16B UGSI I'll give you my two cents. The absolute most important thing is to have a good grasp of the material in 16A, both lab and content. This means being comfortable with the linear algebra you see in 16A, basic circuit components like resistors/capacitors/op-amps, and good lab practice (using equipment correctly and safely, and good debugging techniques). Apart from that, one thing I see many of our students struggle with is dealing with complex numbers for the first time (this is taught in Math 1B, but many test out of it through AP Calculus, which doesn't cover complex numbers in enough depth). Familiarizing yourself with the various mathematical identities relating to complex exponentials, and the intuition behind use of the complex plane, will serve you well through 16B. Hope that helps!

history.content:
https://piazza.com/class/jccq3d39dkzeu?cid=864

The link above is the learning suggestion (from instructor's perspective) given by Prof. Jaijeet Roychowdhury (instructor of 16B this semester, he is really excellent in teaching). If the link doesn't direct you to the actual post, you may manually join EE 16B forum and search post id 864.

I am taking EE 16B this semester. From my personal experience, the difficulty of 16B is quite tougher than 16A, and even the classmates are more competitive (I could not see how it comes but that's what I experienced in Spring 18). Maybe "do both" would be the ideal solution for you to get all the 16A/B knowledge in Computer Science as a whole, but it may not be the most effective way to simply perform well in 16B. I would like to recommend you to prepare ahead during the summer. Go over the 16B materials including watching webcasts, skimming through Murat Arcak's EE16B reader, trying some practice problems (from exams, HW and discussions) and getting an overall idea what's going on in 16B to prevent yourself falling behind during the semester. In the past three semesters (including Spring 18), the first midterm covered all circuit materials, the second midterm covered systems and SVD (linear algebra is highly involved), and the remaining material were covered as ~60% in final. Force yourself to study ahead might be painful in the first place, once your confidence is built up (e.g. performing very well in midterms) (along with that you've understood the importance of the knowledge), studying will be active, productive and smooth. Hope eventually you will enjoy 16B.

Hello, I'm a rising sophomore who took EE16A Spring 18 semester. I did poorly at the start because I had absolutely no experience in both linear algebra and circuits. I also had no interest in the class because I was intended CS. However, as I learned more, I started to gain interest in the class and realized how important the class was for the future. I would like to do well in EE16B in order to make up for my deficient learning in EE16A. Should I look at the things I learned in EE16A? or should I study for EE16B ahead of time? The answer is probably "do both" but I would like to hear from people who were in a similar situation and took both classes. Any advice would be appreciated. Thank you so much.
history.subject: Advice for EE16B
